steps.text: Construct buildings with preventive design for pest management.
Maintain building to prevent pest entry.
Construct a well-designed building for pest management.
Implement daily pest management programs.
Maintain awareness of federal and state regulations.
Design exterior with short grass, trimmed shrubs, paved access, proper drainage, and gravel strip.
Use proper framing materials and keep them at least four inches from walls.
Seal and clean wall materials.
Maintain smooth, water-free roofs.
Use few windows with transparent glass block and tight-fitting doors.
Eliminate litter, waste, and uncut grass.
Pave dusty roads and maintain lawns.
Ensure proper drainage.
Position lighting away from buildings.
Reduce bird harborage and outside food spillage.
Use rodent, insect, and bird traps.
Maintain housekeeping and implement pest monitoring programs.
Use insecticidal baits and approved insecticides near breeding sites.
Use chemical repellents and avicides where appropriate.
Rodent-proof all openings.
Screen windows.
Block bird access to ledges.
Locate equipment off the floor or sealed to it.
Inspect all incoming vehicles and materials.
Use rodent bait stations where policy permits.
Form an inspection committee.
Identify highest company official as chairman.
Include all department heads.
Review existing activities and compile deficiencies.
Categorize deficiencies under: Pest Control (PC), Operational Methods (OM), Personnel Practices (PP), Maintenance for Sanitation (M), and Cleaning Practices (C).
Wear identifiable uniforms.
Carry necessary tools (flashlights).
Committee members wear identifiable uniforms and carry necessary tools for inspections.
Thoroughly inspect all areas, looking in new places and recording all defects.
Distribute notes to department heads for immediate action.
Departments correct defects immediately.
Committee meets to review uncorrected items and assign realistic correction dates.
Encourage plant-wide cooperation by rewarding good sanitation.
Consider periodic inspections by an outside firm for a fresh perspective.
Maintain standards in pallet-cleaning program, stock storage specifications, and reliable stock rotation method.
Monitor storability using various tools.
Use visual inspection, lights, traps, and attractants for monitoring.
Identify common insect pests in raw grain and processed food: Indianmeal moth, sawtoothed grain beetle, red flour beetle.
Select appropriate trap type based on environment (dusty or clean, hot or cold).
Place traps on the outer perimeter of a facility to intercept pests or lure them away.
Read and understand the label instructions.
Prepare application equipment.
Apply pesticide according to label directions.
Clean and store application equipment properly.
Read label for pest control.
Identify food-handling areas.
Understand types of residual applications: general, spot, and crack & crevice.
Follow regulations for pesticide use in specific locations (nationally and state-level).
Identify the life cycle stages of beetles and moths: egg, larva, pupa, and adult.
Understand that beetles have chewing mouthparts and feed on food during the adult stage.
Recognize that moths have sucking mouthparts and do not feed on solid food as adults but can contaminate products.
Determine that almond moths have forewings that are brown-gray and larvae that are dirty white.
Identify moth species: Almond Moth, Indianmeal Moth, Mediterranean Flour Moth, Mealmoth.
Inspect for signs of moth infestation in food products.
Identify beetle species: Lesser Grain Borer, Cigarette Beetle, Drugstore Beetle, Confused Flour Beetle, Sawtoothed Grain Beetle, Merchant Grain Beetle, Foreign Grain Beetle, Rusty Grain Beetle.
Inspect for signs of beetle infestation in food products.
Implement control measures: Avoidance, sanitation, heat treatment, cold treatment, residual insecticides, space sprays, fumigation.
Identify pests: Foreign Grain Beetle, Rusty Grain Beetle, Spider Beetles, Warehouse Beetle, Cockroaches, Flies, Ants, Bees and Wasps.
Determine pest behavior and preferred conditions.
Implement control measures: sanitation, residual pesticides, dusts, contact sprays, nest treatment, baits.
Identify rodent signs such as droppings, runways, rubmarks, burrows, tracks, and urine.
Understand rodent behavior including their senses, reactions, and agility.
Clean and order facilities to reduce rodent population.
Seal openings larger than 1/4 inch for mice and 1/2 inch for rats.
Use rodent-resistant materials like hardware cloth, sheet metal, and concrete.
Place tracking powders in runways.
Select proper bait based on rodent preference and toxicity.
Place bait stations along walls and runways.
Set traps where rodents will encounter them.
Place traps along walls, in dark corners, behind objects for mice.
Use compressed air sprayer for crack and crevice, spot, and general sprays.
Clean and maintain compressor air sprayer after each use.
Use dusters to apply dusts into voids, cracks, and burrows.
Apply space treating equipment for quick knockdown of flying insects.
Use aerosols, fogs, or mists depending on the application.
Turn off pilot lights before thermal fogging.
Know the cubic footage for thermal fogging.
Wear appropriate respirators during thermal fogging.
Choose the right type of respirator based on label indications and hazard levels.
Perform daily checks for proper respirator fit.

constraints.text: Use IPM approach integrating chemical, physical, cultural, and biological controls.
Maintain daily pest management programs for both facility and surrounding areas.
Adhere to federal and state regulations.
Require an 18-inch space between pallets and walls for inspections.
A written inspection procedure is required by law for raw product receiving.
Maintain proper conditions to prevent pest development.
Match trap type to the environment and adapt to changing temperature gradients throughout the year.
Ensure proper personal protective equipment (PPE) is worn during application.
Follow all label restrictions, such as re-entry intervals and buffer zones.
Ensure pesticide use complies with labeling and regulations.
Ensure proper identification of beetles and moths to apply appropriate pest control measures.
Understand the importance of identifying the life cycle stages for effective pest management.
Check for signs of moth or beetle infestation before consuming food products.
Properly store food products to prevent infestations.
Pests can contaminate food and spread diseases.
Control starts with sanitation and removal of breeding sites.
Identify the species of rodents based on droppings shape.
Use tamper-proof bait stations to protect bait and prevent access by children and non-target animals.
Place traps every 10 feet for mice and 20 feet for rats.
Properly maintain compressor air sprayer for safety and effectiveness.
Use appropriate nozzles for different spray patterns.
Wear respirators during thermal fogging to avoid inhalation hazards.
Follow label instructions for respirator use.
